elements.content: The synthesis of two new bifuctional ligand sytems incorporating two different “classical” coordination units connected by a bent (but flexible) thioether linkage is reported. The new systems are the β-diketone-pyridyl derivative, 3-(pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione (L ), and its hydrazine condensation product, the pyridyl-pyrazole species 4-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-ylthio)pyridine (L ). Both systems were designed for use in metal−organic framework studies. With L 1 , four metal-containing products were crystallized, [Cu(L 1 −H)2] n (1), {[Cu(L 1 −H)2]·0.5H2O·CHCl3} n (2), {[Zn(L 1 −H)2]·2H2O} n (3), and [Zn(L 1 −H)2]·2MeOH} n (4); these display three different array types. Compound 1 incorporates 5-coordinate Cu(II) ions with square pyramidal stereochemistry. The β-diketonato groups from two ligands coordinate in the basal plane with the apical position occupied by a pyridyl nitrogen from a third ligand that bridges to an adjacent copper center. Propagation of this coordination motif produces a 1D chain. In 2, which is a pseudo-polymorphic phase of 1, each Cu(II) ion is 6-coordinate with each metal center being bound by two bidentate β-diketonato groups and two pyridyl donors from four different ligands in a cis configuration. The ligand arrangement bridges each metal to four others producing an infinite 2D rhombic grid [(4,4) net]. The grids stack to form channels containing disordered water and chloroform molecules; the solvent-accessible space is 33% of the crystal volume. Crystals of 3 are isostructural with 2, except that they incorporate water as the only solvate in the channels. The solvent-accessible voids constitute 22% of the crystal volume, reflecting closer packing of adjacent grids. A TGA study showed that the water molecules are removed by 375 K and that the resulting desolvated complex is stable up to 573 K. Compound 4 is a pseudo-polymorph of 3 in which the 6-coordinate Zn(II) coordination is similar to that in 3 but with polymeric connectivity producing a chiral [8,4] type 3D network (space group P41212). Helical channels corresponding to 25% of the crystal volume run parallel to the 4-fold axes and are occupied by methanol guests. With 4-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-ylthio)pyridine (L 2 ), an extended array consisting of zwitterionic [Co(L 2 +H)Cl3] n (5) units linked by hydrogen bonds and the metal-linked molecular framework species{[Zn(L 2 )Cl2]·0.5H2O} n (6) were obtained. The cobalt center in 5 is tetrahedrally coordinated by three chloride ions and a pyrazole nitrogen from (L 2 +H); the protonation is present at the pyridyl nitrogen atom. This protonated pyridyl nitrogen forms a charge-assisted hydrogen bond of type N−H+···Cl with a coordinated chloride from an adjacent complex to yield a hydrogen-bonded chainlike array. Intermolecular N−H···Cl hydrogen bonds also exist between the non-deprotonated pyrazole nitrogen and adjacent chloro ligands. Each tetrahedral Zn(II) center in 6 is coordinated to two chloride ions, a pyridyl nitrogen from one L 2 ligand and a pyrazole nitrogen from another. Each L 2 thus bridges adjacent Zn(II) centers, forming 1D polymeric chains that aggregate in the crystal to produce narrow channels occupied by water molecules.

elements.content: Two new difunctional ligand derivatives incorporating “classical” terminal pyridyl, acetylacetone, and/or pyrazole metal coordination sites have been demonstrated to yield five metal−organic frameworks in which the respective ligands link metal centers and one system involving an unusual hydrogen-bonded bridged array incorporating zwitterionic complex units.
elements.clean_text: Two new difunctional ligand derivatives incorporating "classical" terminal pyridyl, acetylacetone, and/or pyrazole metal coordination sites have been demonstrated to yield five metal-organic frameworks in which the respective ligands link metal centers and one system involving an unusual hydrogen-bonded bridged array incorporating zwitterionic complex units.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of both discrete and extended metallo-assemblies, particularly those with interesting topologies and/or potential technological applications, have received much recent attention. In particular, interest in new metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) continues to increase, in part motivated by the unusual structures and properties often associated with such materials. For example, frameworks showing luminescence, nonlinear optical, magnetic spin-crossover, and other unusual magnetic properties have all been documented. It has now also been well-established that a number of porous metal−organic framework materials show very considerable promise as alternatives to zeolites in a range of applications. In particular, there has been much interest in such materials for gas storage, for use in catalysis, and as ion-exchange materials. Linear nitrogen-containing bridging ligands, typified by 4,4‘-bipyridyl, commonly feature in such materials, whereas nonlinear analogues have been less-employed for such studies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of both discrete and extended metallo-assemblies, particularly those with interesting topologies and/or potential technological applications, have received much recent attention. In particular, interest in new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) continues to increase, in part motivated by the unusual structures and properties often associated with such materials. For example, frameworks showing luminescence, nonlinear optical, magnetic spin-crossover, and other unusual magnetic properties have all been documented. It has now also been well-established that a number of porous metal-organic framework materials show very considerable promise as alternatives to zeolites in a range of applications. In particular, there has been much interest in such materials for gas storage, for use in catalysis, and as ion-exchange materials. Linear nitrogen-containing bridging ligands, typified by 4,4‘-bipyridyl, commonly feature in such materials, whereas nonlinear analogues have been less-employed for such studies.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the synthesis of two new nonlinear bifunctional ligands, 3-(pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione (L 1 ) and its derivative, 4-(4-pyridyl)pyrazole (L 2 ), both designed for use as nonlinear organic components in metal−organic framework studies. Each ligand incorporates two “classical” coordination units bridged by a bent thioether linkage. Overall, a range of structural variations in the frameworks formed by these simple ligands appeared possible and, in part, the exploration of these possibilities provided a motivation for the present investigation. In accord with this, the present study confirms that both ligands yield new metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) incorporating Cu(II) and Zn(II) as well as a hydrogen-bonded linked zwitterionic Co(II) array incorporating the protonated ligand species (L 2 +H)+.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we report the synthesis of two new nonlinear bifunctional ligands, 3-(pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione (L  1  ) and its derivative, 4-(4-pyridyl)pyrazole (L  2  ), both designed for use as nonlinear organic components in metal-organic framework studies. Each ligand incorporates two "classical" coordination units bridged by a bent thioether linkage. Overall, a range of structural variations in the frameworks formed by these simple ligands appeared possible and, in part, the exploration of these possibilities provided a motivation for the present investigation. In accord with this, the present study confirms that both ligands yield new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) incorporating Cu(II) and Zn(II) as well as a hydrogen-bonded linked zwitterionic Co(II) array incorporating the protonated ligand species (L  2  +H)+.

With respect to the above, it needs to be noted that the related linear bifunctional ligand, 3-(4-pyridyl)pentane-2,4-dione (PyacH), in which the pyridyl group is directly connected to the 3-position of the pentane-2,4-dione fragment, has been demonstrated to be a versatile system for generating metal coordination polymers. This system gives rise to a diverse range of one- and two-dimensional frameworks, with, for example, linear polymeric, ladder, and square-grid structures all being observed. In typical studies, square planar Cu(Pyac)2 and tetrahedral Be(Pyac)2 units have been employed as tectons for construction of superstructures through interaction with homo- or heterometal ion centers in adjacent molecules via their pendent pyridyl groups; both mixed-valence and mixed-metal ion MOFs have been generated in this manner.

This system gives rise to a diverse range of one- and two-dimensional frameworks, with, for example, linear polymeric, ladder, and square-grid structures all being observed. In typical studies, square planar Cu(Pyac)2 and tetrahedral Be(Pyac)2 units have been employed as tectons for construction of superstructures through interaction with homo- or heterometal ion centers in adjacent molecules via their pendent pyridyl groups; both mixed-valence and mixed-metal ion MOFs have been generated in this manner.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used without purification. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance DPX200 or DPX300 spectrometers; ΔH values are relative to Me4Si at 0 ppm. Low-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS) were obtained on a Finnigan LCQ-8 spectrometer. High-resolution mass spectra (HR-MS) were collected on a 7T Bruker BioApex II FTICR with an Analytica ESI source. TGA analysis was performed using a TA instruments HI-Res TGA2850 thermogravimetric analyzer. The ramp rate for heating (under nitrogen) was 2 °C/min and heating was terminated at 500 °C. Unless otherwise stated, all new compounds were dried over phosphorus pentoxide in a vacuum before microanalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used without purification. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance DPX200 or DPX300 spectrometers; ΔH values are relative to Me4Si at 0 ppm. Low-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS) were obtained on a Finnigan LCQ-8 spectrometer. High-resolution mass spectra (HR-MS) were collected on a 7T Bruker BioApex II FTICR with an Analytica ESI source. TGA analysis was performed using a TA instruments HI-Res TGA2850 thermogravimetric analyzer. The ramp rate for heating (under nitrogen) was 2 °C/min and heating was terminated at 500 °C. Unless otherwise stated, all new compounds were dried over phosphorus pentoxide in a vacuum before microanalysis.

elements.content: Ligand and Metal Complex Synthesis of 3-(Pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione·HCl·H 2 O (L 1 ·HCl·H 2 O). 4-Mercaptopyridine (1.11 g, 0.01 mol) was dissolved in methanol (20 mL) under nitrogen, and the solution was stirred at ambient temperature while 3-chloro-2,4-pentanedione (1.34 g, 0.01 mol) in methanol (10 mL) was slowly added. Stirring was maintained for 24 h (under nitrogen). The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the solid product obtained was washed three times with diethyl ether (30 mL) and then dissolved in acetonitrile (30 mL). This solution was filtered and its volume was reduced on a rotary evaporator to give a yellow product. Yield, 1.80 g (86%). ESI-MS (m/z):  210 (M + H+). 1H NMR (200 MHz, CD3CN, 300 K) :  1.98 (s, CH3, 3H), 2.30 (s, CH3, 3H), 7.70 (d, pyridine, 2H), 8.43 (d, pyridine, 2H), 17.62 (br s, enol, H). Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H11ClNO2S·HCl·H2O:  C, 45.54; H, 5.35; N, 5.31. Found:  C, 45.50, metal and mixed-valence E ions have also been characterized; H, 5.34; N, 5.35.

elements.content: Synthesis of {[Cu(L 1 -H) 2 ]·1.5H 2 O·0.5MeOH} n . 3-(Pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione·HCl·H2O (0.66 mmol, 0.161 g.) in water/methanol (50/50; 100 mL) was added to copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.33 mmol, 0.08 g) in water/methanol (50/50; 100 mL). The resulting solution was stirred and warmed (40 °C) and NaHCO3 (0.96 mmol, 0.081 g) in water/methanol (50/50; 50 mL) was then added; the solution was heated and stirred for a further 5 h. The solution was let stand at room temperature and the fine green precipitate that formed was filtered off and washed with diethyl ether (30 mL). Yield:  0.05 g. Anal. Calcd (%) for C20H20N2O4S2Cu·1.5H2O·0.5MeOH:  C, 47.07; H, 4.82; N, 5.36. Found:  C, 47.11; H, 4.63; N, 5.44. Single crystals (blue/green) of [Cu(L 1 -H)2] n suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by dissolving the green solid in methanol and allowing the solution to stand for several days. Single crystals (light green) of {[Cu(L 1 -H)2]·0.5H2O·CHCl3} n , suitable for X-ray diffraction, were obtained by diffusion of ether vapor into a solution of the green solid in a chloroform/methanol mixture (92:1) over 1 day. On standing for a longer period, the solution subsequently also yielded blue/green crystals that were confirmed by unit−cell determination to be isomophous with [Cu(L 1 -H)2] n .

elements.content: Synthesis of {[Zn(L 1 -H) 2 ]·2H 2 O} n and {[Zn(L 1 -H) 2 ]·2MeOH} n . The above psuedo-polymorphic forms were obtained through slow diffusion of a solution comprising zinc(II) acetate dihydrate (0.026 g, 0.12 mmol) in 1:1 water:methanol (10 mL) into a 1:1 water:methanol (10 mL) solution of 3-(pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione·HCl·H2O (0.056 g, 0.23 mmol) with the aid of an H-shaped tube. One side of the tube contained zinc(II) acetate solution, whereas the other was occupied by 3-(pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione·HCl·H2O solution. Methanol:water (1:1) was then added carefully to one arm of the tube so that a minimum of mixing occurred and until the cross-arm of the H-tube connected both arms with solvent. Light yellow prisms grew over several days and were shown by X-ray analysis to be {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2H2O} n . In a repeat synthesis under what appeared to be similar conditions, light yellow crystals (0.008 g) with a different crystal habit (multifaced blocks) formed. These were shown by a second X-ray structure determination to be of composition {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2MeOH} n and thus represent a pseudo-polymorph of the product from the initial synthesis. In view of this result, the synthesis was repeated using methanol (rather than 1:1 methanol/water) as the reaction solvent, but once again, crystals of {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2H2O} n (confirmed by a unit-cell determination) were obtained. Crystals used for the above X-ray determination were allowed to stand in air and were then dried over P2O5 in a vacuum. Anal. Calcd (%) for C20H20N2O4S2Zn·2H2O:  C, 46.38; H, 4.67; N, 5.41. Found:  C, 46.26; H, 4.50; N, 5.38.

elements.content: Synthesis for 4-(3,5-Dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-ylthio)pyridine·0.66HCl (L 2 ·0.66HCl). 3-(Pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione.HCl (0.98 g, 0.004 mol) was dissolved in ethanol (25 mL), and hydrazine hydrate (0.29 mL, 0.006 mol) was added with stirring. The mixture was refluxed for 5 h and then cooled and filtered to remove a small amount of white precipitate. The filtrate was taken to dryness using a rotary evaporator. The yellow residue was washed with diethyl ether (30 mL) and then dissolved in ethanol (30 mL). The solution was again filtered and the filtrate was taken to dryness on the rotary evaporator. The product obtained in this way was a white solid. Yield, 0.71 g. 1H NMR (200 MHz, DMSO, 300K):  2.53 (s, 2CH3, 6H), 7.45 (d, pyridine, 2H), 8.56 (d, pyridine, 2H). Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H11N3S·0.66HCl:  C, 52.36; H, 5.12; N, 18.32. Found:  C, 52.38; H, 5.43; N, 18.55. HRMS (+ESI) Found:  206.07553. Calcd for[M+H]+:  206.07591.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Co(L 2 +H)Cl 3 ] n . Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (0.100 g, 0.34 mmol) was added to 4-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-ylthio)pyridine·0.66HCl (0.066 g, 0.29 mmol) in acetonitrile (30 mL) at 70 °C. The resulting deep blue solution was warmed until the volume had been reduced to 15 mL. Dark blue crystals formed on allowing the solution to stand. These were isolated and dried in air. Yield:  0.01 g. Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H12CoCl3N3S:  C, 32.32; H, 3.26; N, 11.31. Found:  C, 32.74; H, 3.48; N, 11.81.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Zn(L 2 )Cl 2 ·1.5H 2 O] n . 4-(3,5-Dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-ylthio)pyridine·0.66HCl (0.047 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (30 mL) at 70 °C and zinc(II) nitrate tetrahydrate (0.058 g, 0.22 mmol) was added. The pale yellow solution was stirred and allowed to evaporate at 70 °C until the volume was 15 mL. This solution was allowed to stand at room temperature and colorless crystals formed, one of which was used directly for single-crystal X-ray analysis (and modeled as the hemihydrate). The remaining crystals were isolated and allowed to stand in air before analysis. Yield:  0.01 g. Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H11Cl2N3SZn·1.5H2O:  C, 32.59; H, 3.83; N, 11.40. Found:  C, 32.49; H, 3.38; N, 11.48.

elements.content: X-r ay Structure Determinations. X-ray data were collected at 150(2) K with ω scans to approximately 56° 2θ using a Bruker SMART 1000 diffractometer employing graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation generated from a sealed tube (0.71073 Å). Data integration and reduction were undertaken with SAINT and XPREP. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR97 and refined with SHELXL-97 using the WinGX-32 graphical user interface. Multiscan empirical absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. Ordered non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Disordered non-hydrogen atoms with occupancies less than or equal to 0.5 were refined isotropically. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were included in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Hydrogen atoms attached to oxygen and nitrogen atoms that were identifiable in the Fourier difference map were included and refined with suitable geometric restraints. Hydrogen atoms of disordered water molecules were not located in the difference map and were not therefore included in the refinement models. Crystal data are supplied in Table and selected bond lengths and angles are supplied in Tables S1 and S2 of the Supporting Information.

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The syntheses of the bifunctional ligands L  1   and L  2   have not been reported previously and were carried out using straight-forward and well-established organic coupling and condensation procedures (see Experimental Section).

elements.content: Synthesis of Metal − Organic Arrays. Interaction of L 1 with Cu(II) and Zn(II) under the conditions detailed in the Experimental Section resulted in the formation of four new crystalline compounds displaying three different polymeric architectures:  [Cu(L 1 -H)2] n (1), {[Cu(L 1 -H)2]·0.5H2O·CHCl3} n (2), which is isostructural with {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2H2O} n (3) and [Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2MeOH} n (4). The polymeric frameworks in these structures exhibit one-, two-, two-, and three-dimensional connectivity, respectively. Interaction of L 2 with Co(II) led to the isolation of [Co(L 2 +H)Cl3] n (5) showing hydrogen-bonded connectivity between complex units, whereas Zn(II) yielded the metal-linked framework {[Zn(L 2 )Cl2] n ·0.5H2O} n (6).
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of Metal - Organic Arrays. The polymeric frameworks in these structures exhibit one-, two-, two-, and three-dimensional connectivity, respectively. Interaction of L  2   with Co(II) led to the isolation of [Co(L  2  +H)Cl3] n  (5) showing hydrogen-bonded connectivity between complex units, whereas Zn(II) yielded the metal-linked framework {[Zn(L  2  )Cl2] n ⋅0.5H2O} n  (6).

elements.content: Crystal Structures. Crystallization of [Cu(L 1 -H)2]·1.5H2O·0.5MeOH from methanol produced blue/green crystals of [Cu(L 1 -H)2] n (1), the asymmetric unit of which is illustrated in Figure . The Cu(II) center is 5-coordinate and approximately square pyramidal with the β-diketonato groups coordinating in a square planar arrangement.

elements.content: The Cu(II) centers are connected to form a 1D polymer by the coordination of the pyridyl nitrogen, N(1), to the apical position of the adjacent Cu(II) ion, as illustrated in Figure . The pyridyl nitrogen, N(2), remains unbound and plays no role in propagation of the polymeric architecture. The pyridyl rings of the ligand project on the same side of the plane of the square base of the metal complex in a cis-like conformation. There are intrachain π-interactions between the N(1)-containing pyridyl ring and the N(2)-containing pyridyl ring of both the edge-to-face type (C(17)−H···N(1)-C(6−10)plane = 2.7 Å) and the offset face-to-face type (N(1)−C(6−10)plane···N(2)−C(16−20)plane = 4.0 Å).

elements.content: Crystals of a pseudo-polymorphic phase of 1, namely {[Cu(L 1 -H)2]·0.5H2O·CHCl3} n (2), were obtained by diffusion of ether into a solution of [Cu(L 1 -H)2]·1.5H2O·0.5MeOH in methanol and water (92:1). The Cu(II) centers are octahedral, each being bound in a cis-configuration by two β-diketonato groups with the remaining two coordination sites occupied by pyridyl donors (Figure ).

elements.content: Four ligands bridge each Cu(II) center to four other centers to produce a 2D polymeric framework with rhombic gridlike topology, as illustrated in Figure . Contiguous 2D grids are offset with the result that channels are formed that run parallel to the ac diagonal, Figure ; the H2O and CHCl3 solvate molecules are located within the channels.

elements.content: Reaction of L 1 with zinc(II) acetate in separate but otherwise similar H-tube experiments with a 1:1 (methanol:water) solvent mixture produced crystals of two distinct habits, identified by single-crystal X-ray analyses to be {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2H2O} n (3) and [Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2MeOH} n (4), respectively. Interestingly, a third synthesis using only methanol as the reaction solvent resulted in crystals of 3 being isolated.
elements.clean_text: Reaction of L  1   with zinc(II) acetate in separate but otherwise similar H-tube experiments with a 1:1 (methanol:water) solvent mixture produced crystals of two distinct habits, identified by single-crystal X-ray analyses to be {[Zn(L  1  -H)2]⋅2H2O} n  (3) and [Zn(L  1  -H)2]⋅2MeOH} n  (4), respectively. Interestingly, a third synthesis using only methanol as the reaction solvent resulted in crystals of 3 being isolated.

elements.content: The Cu(II)-containing framework 2 is essentially isostructural with that in 3 (see above; the asymmetric unit for 2 is shown in Figure ). Although the polymeric connectivity in 3 is identical to that in 2, the structure of 3 is solvated with two water molecules per formula unit, in contrast to one chloroform molecule and half a water molecule per formula unit for 2. The unit cell of 3 (2537 Å3) is ∼10% smaller than that of 2 (2806 Å3), the largest dimensional difference being along the c-axis (16.088(4) Å for 3 and 17.5303(5) Å for 2). This is the direction of the lattice along which the polymeric 2D grids stack. The separation of contiguous grids (perpendicular distance:  mean plane···mean plane) is 8.568 Å in 2 but only 7.924 Å in 3. The solvent-accessible void in 2 (occupied by water and chloroform) was calculated using PLATON to be 922 Å3 per unit cell, which constitutes 33% of the total crystal volume. In contrast, the solvent-accessible void in 3 (occupied by water) is 561 Å3 per cell, which constitutes only 22% of the crystal volume. The diagonal distances between metal centers across the rhombic grids are only marginally smaller in 3 than in 2 (14.938 and 10.720 Å for 3 and 14.831 and 11.042 Å for 2), and the coordination bond lengths and angles for the two structures are almost identical. There are no directional intermolecular interactions (specifically H-bond or π-interactions) between the components of contiguous grids and thus the spatial differences between the two structures appear to reflect the different solvation in each lattice, with the larger chloroform molecules present in 2 apparently invoking a larger separation of the 2D grids.

elements.content: Three-dimensional network connectivity is often associated with stable crystals robust enough to undergo thermally induced solvation/desolvation, and the prospect of this occurring for 3 was probed. A thermogravimetric analysis of a bulk sample of 3 from 293 to 720 K at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min under nitrogen revealed that the structure loses its solvent molecules by 350 K. The sample then maintains constant mass until 570 K, when it decomposes. On the basis of these results, a “high”-temperature X-ray study (373 K) was attempted. A single crystal was mounted on a glass capillary and the crystal held in a stream of dry nitrogen at 373 K for an hour before the unit cell data were collected. The results confirm the expected volume change with temperature:  the unit cell volume increases from 2537 Å3 to 2597 Å3 (2%), with corresponding changes in axis and angle measurements (10.720(3), 14.938(4), 16.088(4), 99.899(5) to 11.342(5), 14.745(4), 15.906(3), 102.539(5)). A full data collection was then attempted; however, after approximately 25% of data had been collected the crystal lost crystallinity. A crude solution using the limited data (R-factor 18.5%) was consistent with the loss of the solvent molecules from the solvated structure.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit for {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2MeOH} n (4) (Figure ) is similar to that in 3 (Figure ). The Zn(II) center is octahedral with two deprotonated L 1 ligands coordinating via their β-diketonato groups in a cis-configuration and a further two such ligands coordinating via their pyridyl nitrogen donors. Each Zn(II) center is connected to four others by ligand bridges, resulting in the formation of a 3D polymeric framework with 8,4 network connectivity. The 8-membered loop of the network is illustrated in Figure .

elements.content: The framework in 4 is chiral (space group P41212), and the correct absolute configuration, which has the metal centers in this crystal with Δ stereochemistry, was confirmed by the refined value of the Flack parameter (0.035(14)). The framework twists upon itself along the 4-fold axis, creating helical channels (Figure ) that are occupied by methanol molecules. These solvent-accessible channels constitute 24% of the total crystal volume.

elements.content: The coordination geometry of each Co(II) in 5 is approximately tetrahedral with the metal coordinated to three chloro ligands and the pyrazole nitrogen donor atom of (L 2 +H) (protonation in the latter occurs at the pyridyl nitrogen atom). An intramolecular hydrogen bond is present between the pyrazole NH (donor) and a coordinated choride (acceptor) (N(2)−H(2A)···Cl(1), N to Cl distance 3.332(2) Å, N−H···Cl angle 118.4°). The above entities are arranged in linear chains (Figure ) that propagate parallel to the ab diagonal, linked by charge-assisted intermolecular hydrogen bonds of the type N−H+···Cl between the protonated pyridyl group and a chloro group on an adjacent molecule in the chain (N(3)−H(3A)+···Cl(1), N to Cl distance 3.124(2) Å, N−H···Cl angle 174.7°). Adjacent chains are arranged in layers parallel to the ab plane and are connected to contiguous chains by hydrogen bonds between the pyrazole NH and coordinated chloro ligands (N(2)−H(2A)···Cl(2), N to Cl distance 3.338(2) Å, N−H···Cl angle 145.5°).
elements.clean_text: The coordination geometry of each Co(II) in 5 is approximately tetrahedral with the metal coordinated to three chloro ligands and the pyrazole nitrogen donor atom of (L  2   +H) (protonation in the latter occurs at the pyridyl nitrogen atom). An intramolecular hydrogen bond is present between the pyrazole NH (donor) and a coordinated choride (acceptor)  (N(2)-H(2A)⋅⋅⋅Cl(1), N to Cl distance 3.332(2) Å, N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl angle 118.4°). The above entities are arranged in linear chains (Figure ) that propagate parallel to the ab diagonal, linked by charge-assisted intermolecular hydrogen bonds of the type N-H+⋅⋅⋅Cl between the protonated pyridyl group and a chloro group on an adjacent molecule in the chain (N(3)-H(3A)+⋅⋅⋅Cl(1), N to Cl distance 3.124(2) Å, N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl angle 174.7°). Adjacent chains are arranged in layers parallel to the ab plane and are connected to contiguous chains by hydrogen bonds between the pyrazole NH and coordinated chloro ligands (N(2)-H(2A)⋅⋅⋅Cl(2), N to Cl distance 3.338(2) Å, N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl angle 145.5°).

elements.content: The polymeric chains flank one another producing a framework with narrow channels that run parallel to the c-axis (in- line with the polymeric chains), with the channels being occupied by water molecules (Figure ). The channels are, in fact, partitioned into what approximates cavities by the bulky surfaces of the bounding atoms, with the latter including chloride ions, sulfur atoms, and pyridyl edges. The solvent-accessible volume of these channels constitutes less than 5% of the total lattice volume and thus the porosity of the system is minimal, particularly when compared with the frameworks incorporating L 1 .

elements.content: The present study introduces two new, readily synthesized, nonlinear difunctional ligands incorporating “classical” terminal pyridyl, acetylacetone and/or pyrazole metal coordination groups, designed to bridge metal ions in a nonlinear fashion. With L 1 , this feature has been exemplified by the isolation and characterization of four new MOFs that exploit the nonlinear coordination vectors present in each ligand. With L 2 , a further metal-coordination linked framework was generated along with an unusual hydrogen-bonded bridged array incorporating zwiterionic complex units. The respective frameworks incorporate solvent-accessible voids in their structures that range from 5% of the crystal volume in the case of {[Zn(L 2 )Cl2]n·0.5H2O} n to 33% in the case of {Cu(L 1 -H)2]n·0.5H2O·CHCl3} n . In one case, the robustness of the metallo framework was demonstrated by its stability up to 573 K following loss of solvent water from its crystal. Clearly, the structures of L 1 and L 2 open the way for the construction of new mixed-metal and mixed-ligand MOFs (for example, in the latter case with the new ligands employed as secondary building blocks (SUBs)2). Studies of these types are planned for the future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The present study introduces two new, readily synthesized, nonlinear difunctional ligands incorporating "classical" terminal pyridyl, acetylacetone and/or pyrazole metal coordination groups, designed to bridge metal ions in a nonlinear fashion. With L  1  , this feature has been exemplified by the isolation and characterization of four new MOFs that exploit the nonlinear coordination vectors present in each ligand. With L  2  , a further metal-coordination linked framework was generated along with  an unusual hydrogen-bonded bridged array incorporating zwiterionic complex units. The respective frameworks incorporate solvent-accessible voids in their structures that range from 5% of the crystal volume in the case of {[Zn(L  2  )Cl2]n⋅0.5H2O} n  to 33% in the case of {Cu(L  1  -H)2]n⋅0.5H2O⋅CHCl3} n . In one case, the robustness of the metallo framework was demonstrated by its stability up to 573 K following loss of solvent water from its crystal. Clearly, the structures of L  1   and L  2   open the way for the construction of new mixed-metal and mixed-ligand MOFs (for example, in the latter case with the new ligands employed as secondary building blocks (SUBs)2). Studies of these types are planned for the future.

Ligand and Metal Complex Synthesis of 3-(Pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione·HCl·H 2 O (L 1 ·HCl·H 2 O). 4-Mercaptopyridine (1.11 g, 0.01 mol) was dissolved in methanol (20 mL) under nitrogen, and the solution was stirred at ambient temperature while 3-chloro-2,4-pentanedione (1.34 g, 0.01 mol) in methanol (10 mL) was slowly added. Stirring was maintained for 24 h (under nitrogen). The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the solid product obtained was washed three times with diethyl ether (30 mL) and then dissolved in acetonitrile (30 mL). This solution was filtered and its volume was reduced on a rotary evaporator to give a yellow product. Yield, 1.80 g (86%). ESI-MS (m/z):  210 (M + H+). 1H NMR (200 MHz, CD3CN, 300 K) :  1.98 (s, CH3, 3H), 2.30 (s, CH3, 3H), 7.70 (d, pyridine, 2H), 8.43 (d, pyridine, 2H), 17.62 (br s, enol, H). Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H11ClNO2S·HCl·H2O:  C, 45.54; H, 5.35; N, 5.31. Found:  C, 45.50, metal and mixed-valence E ions have also been characterized; H, 5.34; N, 5.35.

Synthesis of {[Cu(L 1 -H) 2 ]·1.5H 2 O·0.5MeOH} n . 3-(Pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione·HCl·H2O (0.66 mmol, 0.161 g.) in water/methanol (50/50; 100 mL) was added to copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.33 mmol, 0.08 g) in water/methanol (50/50; 100 mL). The resulting solution was stirred and warmed (40 °C) and NaHCO3 (0.96 mmol, 0.081 g) in water/methanol (50/50; 50 mL) was then added; the solution was heated and stirred for a further 5 h. The solution was let stand at room temperature and the fine green precipitate that formed was filtered off and washed with diethyl ether (30 mL). Yield:  0.05 g. Anal. Calcd (%) for C20H20N2O4S2Cu·1.5H2O·0.5MeOH:  C, 47.07; H, 4.82; N, 5.36. Found:  C, 47.11; H, 4.63; N, 5.44. Single crystals (blue/green) of [Cu(L 1 -H)2] n suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by dissolving the green solid in methanol and allowing the solution to stand for several days. Single crystals (light green) of {[Cu(L 1 -H)2]·0.5H2O·CHCl3} n , suitable for X-ray diffraction, were obtained by diffusion of ether vapor into a solution of the green solid in a chloroform/methanol mixture (92:1) over 1 day. On standing for a longer period, the solution subsequently also yielded blue/green crystals that were confirmed by unit−cell determination to be isomophous with [Cu(L 1 -H)2] n .

Synthesis of {[Zn(L 1 -H) 2 ]·2H 2 O} n and {[Zn(L 1 -H) 2 ]·2MeOH} n . The above psuedo-polymorphic forms were obtained through slow diffusion of a solution comprising zinc(II) acetate dihydrate (0.026 g, 0.12 mmol) in 1:1 water:methanol (10 mL) into a 1:1 water:methanol (10 mL) solution of 3-(pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione·HCl·H2O (0.056 g, 0.23 mmol) with the aid of an H-shaped tube. One side of the tube contained zinc(II) acetate solution, whereas the other was occupied by 3-(pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione·HCl·H2O solution. Methanol:water (1:1) was then added carefully to one arm of the tube so that a minimum of mixing occurred and until the cross-arm of the H-tube connected both arms with solvent. Light yellow prisms grew over several days and were shown by X-ray analysis to be {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2H2O} n . In a repeat synthesis under what appeared to be similar conditions, light yellow crystals (0.008 g) with a different crystal habit (multifaced blocks) formed. These were shown by a second X-ray structure determination to be of composition {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2MeOH} n and thus represent a pseudo-polymorph of the product from the initial synthesis. In view of this result, the synthesis was repeated using methanol (rather than 1:1 methanol/water) as the reaction solvent, but once again, crystals of {[Zn(L 1 -H)2]·2H2O} n (confirmed by a unit-cell determination) were obtained. Crystals used for the above X-ray determination were allowed to stand in air and were then dried over P2O5 in a vacuum. Anal. Calcd (%) for C20H20N2O4S2Zn·2H2O:  C, 46.38; H, 4.67; N, 5.41. Found:  C, 46.26; H, 4.50; N, 5.38.

Synthesis for 4-(3,5-Dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-ylthio)pyridine·0.66HCl (L 2 ·0.66HCl). 3-(Pyridin-4-ylthio)pentane-2,4-dione.HCl (0.98 g, 0.004 mol) was dissolved in ethanol (25 mL), and hydrazine hydrate (0.29 mL, 0.006 mol) was added with stirring. The mixture was refluxed for 5 h and then cooled and filtered to remove a small amount of white precipitate. The filtrate was taken to dryness using a rotary evaporator. The yellow residue was washed with diethyl ether (30 mL) and then dissolved in ethanol (30 mL). The solution was again filtered and the filtrate was taken to dryness on the rotary evaporator. The product obtained in this way was a white solid. Yield, 0.71 g. 1H NMR (200 MHz, DMSO, 300K):  2.53 (s, 2CH3, 6H), 7.45 (d, pyridine, 2H), 8.56 (d, pyridine, 2H). Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H11N3S·0.66HCl:  C, 52.36; H, 5.12; N, 18.32. Found:  C, 52.38; H, 5.43; N, 18.55. HRMS (+ESI) Found:  206.07553. Calcd for[M+H]+:  206.07591.

Synthesis of [Co(L 2 +H)Cl 3 ] n . Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (0.100 g, 0.34 mmol) was added to 4-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-ylthio)pyridine·0.66HCl (0.066 g, 0.29 mmol) in acetonitrile (30 mL) at 70 °C. The resulting deep blue solution was warmed until the volume had been reduced to 15 mL. Dark blue crystals formed on allowing the solution to stand. These were isolated and dried in air. Yield:  0.01 g. Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H12CoCl3N3S:  C, 32.32; H, 3.26; N, 11.31. Found:  C, 32.74; H, 3.48; N, 11.81.

Synthesis of [Zn(L 2 )Cl 2 ·1.5H 2 O] n . 4-(3,5-Dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-ylthio)pyridine·0.66HCl (0.047 g, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (30 mL) at 70 °C and zinc(II) nitrate tetrahydrate (0.058 g, 0.22 mmol) was added. The pale yellow solution was stirred and allowed to evaporate at 70 °C until the volume was 15 mL. This solution was allowed to stand at room temperature and colorless crystals formed, one of which was used directly for single-crystal X-ray analysis (and modeled as the hemihydrate). The remaining crystals were isolated and allowed to stand in air before analysis. Yield:  0.01 g. Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H11Cl2N3SZn·1.5H2O:  C, 32.59; H, 3.83; N, 11.40. Found:  C, 32.49; H, 3.38; N, 11.48.

cln_elements.content: Three-dimensional network connectivity is often associated with stable crystals robust enough to undergo thermally induced solvation/desolvation, and the prospect of this occurring for 3 was probed. A thermogravimetric analysis of a bulk sample of 3 from 293 to 720 K at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min under nitrogen revealed that the structure loses its solvent molecules by 350 K. The sample then maintains constant mass until 570 K, when it decomposes. On the basis of these results, a “high”-temperature X-ray study (373 K) was attempted. A single crystal was mounted on a glass capillary and the crystal held in a stream of dry nitrogen at 373 K for an hour before the unit cell data were collected. The results confirm the expected volume change with temperature:  the unit cell volume increases from 2537 Å3 to 2597 Å3 (2%), with corresponding changes in axis and angle measurements (10.720(3), 14.938(4), 16.088(4), 99.899(5) to 11.342(5), 14.745(4), 15.906(3), 102.539(5)). A full data collection was then attempted; however, after approximately 25% of data had been collected the crystal lost crystallinity. A crude solution using the limited data (R-factor 18.5%) was consistent with the loss of the solvent molecules from the solvated structure.
